column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $1$1$3$"I came off of my medications Prozac 20mg and Wellbutrin 150xr

column1: per day because of a serious heath issue that had me in a coma for about a week and a half. After recovery my doctor tried Effexor as a replacement. The medicine was so bad
column2: I was seriously considering suicide daily and found myself actually looking for trees along the highway which would do the job. I was an avid duck hunter and one day across a pond was a tree. The tree began to move and come toward me across the pond. I immediately went to my doctor who weaned me off of the med.

column1: it took approximately 10-11 months to get off the medicine and get the suicidal thoughts out of my head. I was abusive to my family
column2: which led to a divorce. My career was horribly affected and I lost many friends because of my ups and downs trying to get off of it. It was the worst experience of my life. I’ve heard nothing but horror stories about this medication. Please research it before you try it

3$"Condition: ""Change of Life"" Signs"$12/11/2019 11:25:37 AM$Reviewer: cms
column2: 45-54 on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$5$"At 50
column3: I had a heart attack
column4: bypass surgery and immediately found out I was also in the throes of menopause. I had been on the birth control pill up to the day of my heart attack and that had kept most of the hot flashes away. As soon as I went off the birth control pill
column5: hot flashes hit. Very bad and about 15 per day. Doctor suggested Effexor 37.5mg once a day since I can not take hormones because of heart disease. It took a while (6 weeks) to start working but once it did it was a sure fix for me. Hot flashes happen about 3 times a week now! Decided to come off of it after about 6 months and hot flashes have returned. :(  The worst part however is the withdrawal symptoms. Even at that low dose
column6: coming off has given me a week's worth of dizziness when I move my head. My eyes don't seem to be processing what they see in real time and that makes me dizzy. Also have something I will just reference as the ""brain zaps"" mentioned by others just because I can not describe it. But helping with the hot flashes and mood swings was definitely worth going through the withdrawal ! "

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $2$1$3$"I have been a ""highly funtioning"" depressed person for many years: life of the party

column4: intelligent
column5: charming

column1: ...until I got home. Work was an escape from myself for me. If I had no weekend functions to attend I would be catatonic

column1: I had always felt like an outsider
column2: looking in on life

column1: No not suicidal-many years ago I came to the realization that I can only live once for a limited amount of time

column3: as long as I was alive

column1: About 6 years ago
column2: it was so bad that I stopped sleeping and could not eat

column5: 75mg. Took about 2 weeks to get used to it. Yes

column9: nuts

column1: Apparently I am in the 8% percent that this happens to when taking Effexor. Unfortunately

column1: 25$Condition: Depression$9/25/2016 12:37:05 PM$Reviewer: $3$1$2$"There's a reason this doctors refer to this drug as ""side effexor.""  My Dr. didn't advise me of the significant side effects
column2: including flu-like symptoms if you miss as little as one or two doses.  You can feel seriously ill.  I took it for years
column3: and experienced this pretty much every time I forgot a dose.  When I went to a doctor (a different one than the one who prescribed it
column4: since I lost trust in her due to her failure to inform me about the downsides of Effexor) to get off this Rx
column5: I asked her what the worse case scenario would be if I was traveling in a remote area and the Rx was lost/stolen
column6: as I was planning a trip in Africa.  She said I'd be hospitalized.  It took SIX WEEKS to slowly reduce the dosage and gradually get off this Rx.  I needed the doctor's supervision to do it safely.  I would caution anyone considering taking it to research it thoroughly in advance.  If there are other effective options
column7: I would certainly recommend those instead of Effexor
column8: and consider it a drug of last resort.

column1: 26$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$7/28/2016 6:42:53 PM$Reviewer: itgetsbetter, 19-24 on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$2$3$I was prescribed this drug after being diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder as well as severe anxiety. I have been taking it for almost 4 years
column2: 300 mgs for 3 and 225 mgs for almost a year. Recently
column3: I've realized how bad I felt after missing a dose. I would get the ""brain zaps"" everyone on here is talking about and I would instantly feel more depressed
column4: more likely to have an anxiety attack or to have severe mood swings. I am now trying to come off it and taking 150 mgs a day. I really want to stop taking this drug since I feel like the side effects cause more harm than it's benefits for me. I have been having wild nightmares every night since I began taking it and it has really decreased my sex drive. I feel like it did its job when I first started to use it but it truly is something to thoroughly think about before using since the withdrawal symptoms are very severe."

column1: 27$Condition: Depression$6/14/2016 8:03:01 AM$Reviewer: Timofbedlam
column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$3$2$"By far the most effective antidepressant I have used
column3: but also with the worst side effects and withdrawal symptoms.

column1: I was prescribed Venlafaxine (aka Effexor) after showing limited response to fluoxetine and trazodone (had previously tried amitriptyline
column2: Seroxat
column3: and dusolepin). Venlafaxine alleviated the worst of my depression and anxiety
column4: and allowed me to start consistently getting more than 2 hours sleep per night
column5: for the first time in months. The doctor gradually raised the dose
column6: and I started getting more sleep and feeling less out of control.

column1: The side effects were unpleasant
column2: but still preferable to depression. My mouth and throat were so dry each morning that I had to down a pint or two of water when I awoke
column3: but just swallowing water was painful on such a parched throat. My sex drive diminished drastically. I was constipated. I sweated excessively
column4: especially at night. Cuts and bruises took many times longer than usual to heal. My dreams were very vivid. After a few months
column5: I developed pain and stiffness in the tendons of my fingers and the backs of my hands
column6: and frequent pain in my shoulder joints: writing
column7: typing and playing guitar all became difficult
column8: but it took me a while to make the connection that the medication was causing me to develop tendonitis.

column1: I weaned myself off as quickly as possible
column2: eventually quitting altogether to avoid the side effects. Withdrawal symptoms included weird electrical twinges in my brain
column3: irritability
column4: severe headaches
column5: severely impaired concentration
column6: and insomnia. I have stayed off it ever since
column7: and the tendonitis cleared up. I don't regret taking Venlafaxine
column8: but wish I had insisted on a lower dose and/or stopped taking it earlier. My emotions were numbed and I'm not sure that they've ever recovered to the pre-Venlafaxine levels
column9: even now several years after quitting.

column1: A useful drug for severe depression when nothing else works
column2: but approach with caution and don't take more than absolutely necessary."

33$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$12/31/2015 1:53:52 AM$Reviewer: psych_patient
column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$3$"I'm a college student. I've had MDD since high school
column3: but Zoloft has typically been effective at keeping me in a healthy mood.

column1: However in the last year
column2: Zoloft has started to fail me
column3: and after messing around with the dose for a while
column4: my psych switched me to 75mg of Effexor. I noticed nothing for the first month
column5: so he bumped it to 150mg.

column1: This is where a lot of things changed. I didn't see much of a difference in side effects
column2: however anti-depressants usually make me sweat a lot and give me sticky hands. Nothing major. It did have a great effect on both my mood and my motivation. In the last few months
column3: I have had a horrible time with school
column4: namely with writing. I'm a good writer and I typically receive A's and B's on assignments
column5: however writing became much more difficult for me once Zoloft stopped working. I tended to completely avoid major assignments because they were too overwhelming. I couldn't even look at the assignment pages without becoming extremely anxious. Most of the time I simply procrastinated through the deadline because the stress of  receiving a failing grade was worse than looking at
column6: brainstorming
column7: and drafting an essay. It was pretty bad for me. I couldn't even study for my easier classes either.

column1: So
column2: about 4-6 weeks after switching to the 150mg dose of Effexor
column3: I noticed that writing became easier. Suddenly it didn't give me a panic attack to create an outline for a research essay. I was actually able to study for hours for my finals as well. For my final essay in one course
column4: I procrastinated until the day that it was due (however this time it was because I spent my time studying
column5: not moping around all depressed and anxious). Instead of panicking that I had no time to do it and feeling overwhelmed
column6: I actually seriously sat down and spent all day researching and writing
column7: and I finished it and got an A.

column1: So I became functioning again

column1: 48$Condition: Depression$6/2/2014 7:09:26 AM$Reviewer: overcomer1
column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$Effexor has worked for me every time. Recently I had another episode of depression after a stressful work situation and not pursuing my own goals and hobbies. As it always happens I had forgotten how horrible depression is and I also had some doubts: would Effexor work again? I was very worried for the first two weeks. I read some negative reviews and thought maybe this time the medication would not work. It's part of the disease: we worry too much and expect the worst to happen. Well
column3: I worried in vain: after 4 weeks Effexor kicked in again and I started to feel better
column4: able to work
column5: play
column6: and enjoy life. It's been just over 8 weeks and I feel even better than before I started. About those who complain: there may be some genuine cases when this medication does not work
column7: but in most cases I notice a unfair whining about side effects. I can't understand how can some sweating
column8: nausea or temporary loss of libido compare to the horrible abyss of depression? Well they don't in my case. I have experienced some increased sweating
column9: a bit of nausea for about 2-3 days
column10: and a loss of libido for about 2-3 weeks. But after a matter of weeks the body adjusts and everything is normal. Depression makes us all worry and think negative scenarios. No need to add to that and deter somebody from using a medication that just may work for them. There is hope - whether from this medication or some other treatment. Get well soon everyone and take some action. It's too much I know
column11: but taking the first steps is all that is required.

column1: 51$Condition: Depression$5/11/2014 12:53:35 AM$Reviewer: breadcrumb
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$3$"I took Zolft for 12 years and Paxil for 8 years. Paxil recently started to be less effective for my anxiety and depression
column3: so I was given Effexor as I titrated off of the Paxil. Eventually the Effexor XR was raised to 225 mg per day. At first I thought the effexor would work for me
column4: as my ""old self"" seemed to return. But then I started getting angry and felt intense rage! My personality was changing a LOT and I had suicidal thoughts all the time! I would cry over any little thing and/or get terribly mad! I felt like I was on the verge of a breakdown! I went to my healthcare provider and she has now had me start titrating off of the effexor and has added Prozac. I really do not understand why she ever tried me on effexor in the first place!

column1: Today has been my third day without any effexor. I actually made myself skip a week of the titration! Next week was supposed to be the ""stop it completely"" week. I have been sick in bed all day. Diarrhea
column2: some nausea (vomited once)
column3: and earlier today I had extreme thirst!

column1: Anyway
column2: so far I have not had any brain zaps. But I would suggest to anyone considering this drug to weigh all your options. I would never say to someone to never use it though. It has helped some people immensely. As for me
column3: NO!"

column1: 52$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$4/23/2014 3:22:23 PM$Reviewer: Jared
column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$3$4$"It is difficult to review this medication
column3: because technically it has worked wonders for me
column4: yet miss a dose
column5: and it is absolutely debilitating.  I suffered from panic attacks for years and tried a variety of anti-depressants to treat them.  Most worked marginally well
column6: and usually came with some unwanted side effects
column7: particularly weight gain.  On Effexor
column8: though
column9: I feel like I've had my life returned to me
column10: and there are practically zero side effects
column11: provided you take it every day.  I am able to function so much better on a daily basis
column12: and have been living a fuller life since starting this medication.

column1: Now for the downside.  I once missed a single dose because my pharmacy ran out
column2: and within 6 hours of my normal dose time
column3: I started feeling the effects.  Within 12 hours
column4: I was sweating
column5: nauseated
column6: jittery
column7: confused
column8: etc.  I could barely sleep that night
column9: and when I did
column10: I had horrible nightmares.  The next day
column11: I awoke feeling nothing like myself.  Literally
column12: I felt like a different person was in my body.  I was incredibly irritable and had the worst vertigo I've ever experienced.  It was all I could do to get to the pharmacy once they had more
column13: and within a couple hours of taking my dose
column14: I was nearly back to normal.  After that incident
column15: I did a great deal of research on this drug
column16: and found that my experience was not uncommon at all
column18: nor the warnings on the medication
column19: nor the advice on site like this list any of these problems as a possibility.  I think a lot more people would be very hesitant to start this medication knowing how crippling it would be to try and get off it.  As some other reviewers have said
column20: if there is any other option available to you
column21: even if it doesn't work perfectly
column22: I would strongly advise using that instead of starting an Effexor regiment. God willing
column23: I will never miss a dose again
column24: and God help me if I ever need to stop. :("

column1: Comparing this drug to Zoloft and Lexapro i have noticed best results. And NO weight gain unlike all the others.

I first experienced anti d's when i was 16 and watched my mum stuggle through cancer...she passed away 4 years later. Losing a loved one was the hardest thing i ever could face in life and found my only saviour was anti depressants. They werent forever
column2: i weened off them 9 years later and remained off them for 2 years.

column1: I recently re-commenced the tablets as emotions stirred up with a few other life issues so for now im back on them. Its helping me for now and im happy so thats all that matters. Very few side effects for me so im a happy camper!
I would otherwise cry every day and at the drop of the hat. when i commenced the drug i did have increased thoughts of suicide but that has faded.
I can still orgasm lol but never as good drive as previous. I'd rather happiness everyday than a few seconds of pleasure.
Overall dont knock it until you try it.
I could bag Zoloft for making me violently ill but i know others that took it and are happy.
Two sides to a story people!"

column1: I have tried to go off of Effexor a couple times working with my doctor. I was weaned off and put on another medication over a few months. The withdrawl and side effects were horrid. I was full of rage for no reason and was extremely mean. I can't say for sure my symptoms were caused from withdrawl or were from my depression.
I would highly recommend this medicine if you truly need it but be very careful and research the side effects. Plan on being this medicine forever once you begin."

However for an anti-depressant the side effects have been minimal (moderate weight gain but now I feel more motivated to exercise and manage my weight as a result).
I highly recommend for the right diagnosis.

I had pretty intense weight gain - about 20-25lbs - and it makes me very tired.  I was originally taking 75 in the AM and 150 in the PM, but the 75 made me so tired that I either had to nap again before going to work, or I'd fall asleep during my drive to work.  Scary!  Now I just take both at night.  I frequently have very vivid dreams, and sometimes I can't remember if I dreamt something or if it really happened.  I had brain zaps when I first started and as I increased the dosage, but those have mostly stopped.  But my moods are definitely better overall and my depression has lessened.  I might look into Cymbalta, as I'm really frustrated about the weight gain.
289$Condition: Bipolar Depression$4/1/2010 6:28:17 PM$Reviewer: eh, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I was prescribed Effexor XR 150mg 1x/day nearly 10 years ago as an anti-depressant for bipolar.  I have had no side effects and the medication has worked well with my other medications.  I would also strongly recommend that often times have to give psychiatric drugs 8-12 weeks before they reach a therapeutic level to even work, so give them a chance.  Additionally, don't expect everything from your medications; you should also be involved in counseling and group therapy for an adequate time ( I still go regularly to a psychiatrist and to a therapist) to better help you understand whatever disorder you've been diagnosed with and help you cope with the challenges that go along with it.
290$Condition: Other$3/30/2010 12:54:30 PM$Reviewer: Effexor, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$4$5$I have been taking Effexor for 5+ years - I have Fibromyalgia. If you forget to take a dose one day, not pleasant experience - you feel like you have intense flu and very strange feelings.  Don't like the 50 pounds gained, but Effexor has given me more of a normal life - I am thankful for that.  I sometimes think I should start weaning off this drug, however, I then think of where I was to now, so I then stop and think, what the heck, weight gain, being on a anti depressant - humm, it helps me function - I'll stay on the low dose.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$4$"I have been diagnosed with a medium case of depression around the age of 38 while I was in the military and initially started taking Prozac under doctor's orders.  It helped somewhat but I would still go through bouts of depression.  Once I retired from the military
column3: my new family doctor started prescribing 75mg of Effexor to me.  I have been taking Effexor now for nine years and am quite happy with it.  I rarely suffer from depression now and am much happier with life.  The only side effects I have are if I run out of my prescription and have to wait for more.  I start feeling ""waves"" of nausea and also feel unbalanced.  I cannot function well in normal activities such as driving and cannot concentrate well on work.  Needless to say
column4: there is a degree of dependency on Effexor.  For those that are uncomfortable with feeling dependent on a drug than Effexor is not for you.  For me
column5: getting rid of the feelings of hopelessness and self-pity have made Effexor the antidepressant drug of choice.   "

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"Had life altering mobility changes due to a virus. Continual disabling physical challanges X 7 yrs. Tried Paxil and Celexa for about 2 months with very little success for my profound depression.  The suggestion to try Effexor came from a nurse aide taking care of me in the nursing home because she was taking it herself. I asked MD to try it on me and it has been a Godsend.  I returned to work as a nurse in a wheelchair...then progressed to a 4 wheeled walker. I am no longer in the patient care aspect of nursing but I work full time even with multiple physical challanges and am able to maintain good emotional health as I am continuing to take Effexor. I regularly get MD check ups and have been able to reduce the dosage over time but continue using under dr's orders and supervision and life is Great! (7 yrs post disabling virus infection.)

column1: 382$Condition: Other$4/10/2009 11:20:13 PM$Reviewer: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$1$5$"Effexor or its generic is a ""good and bad"" story for me: good
column2: in that it did a great job at managing my A.D.D. (and the depression that can come from it); bad
column3: because I gained 75 POUNDS while on it! My family doctor thought I had something wrong metabolically. She ran all kinds of tests on liver function
column4: blood sugars
column5: etc. Nothing. No matter how much I exercised or dieted
column6: the weight kept piling on. The clincher was when my wife and I did the South Beach diet. She lost about 15 pounds; I gained about 10 (and no cheating at all). While researching Effexor on the internet
column7: I kept seeing comments about weight gain over and over again. When I asked my psychiatrist about it
column8: he seemed not to know! So we moved me off of Effexor and on to Wellbutrin and a small dose of Prozac. BINGO! I've already lost about 30 pounds in the six months since then
column9: without any change in diet or exercise. In fact
column10: with my crazy schedule (I'm a pastor)
column11: I've exercised LESS in the past six months than I usually do. No doubt - it was the Effexor. I have one warning for anyone reading this who wants to get off: the withdrawal period is going to be really WEIRD! I had some strange effects during the about three weeks it took for the Effexor to filter out of my body. Things like your head feeling like it's whooshing around in a breeze
column12: sudden surges of ""voltage"" through your body (no pain)
column13: occasional minor twitches of muscles for short periods of time. None of it was enough to impair me - it just wasn't very pleasant. If you've gained a bunch of weight while taking Effexor
column14: I'd venture to say: it's the drug. Your psychiatrist can prescribe some combination of other things that will work well for you. My combo of Wellbutrin and Prozac is doing the job admirably for me. Hang  in there! "

I take 75 mg daily.  The first six months were great.  I had some side effects at first
column2: but after a week
column3: they went away almost completely.  It really helped with my anxiety and I was very satisfied.

column1: After about 6 months on Effexor
column2: things started to change and I started feeling pretty bad.  Now I feel a little dizzy and ""drunk"" all of the time.  I also have a minor headache all the time
column3: which occasionally escalates into a debilitating migraine.  I've also noticed I'm more compulsive than I used to be.  For example
column4: I feel a compulsion to do the same things after work every day.  Or
column5: if I start a task (cleaning or gardening for example)
column6: I can't stop until I have finished every single possible related job.

column1: Has anyone else noticed this?  My first instinct is to stop taking it.  Has anyone else had a similar experience?  I don't really know what to do now.  I don't want to feel anxious any more
column2: but I also don't want to feel the way I feel right now.  Any comments would be appreciated!"

column3: Paxil
column4: and Zoloft with no success. I finally tried Effexor and it worked! I lost the feelings of hopelessness
column5: I found I was able to smile
column6: I regained some energy and generally felt better. At the end of the HEP C treatment I stopped the Effexor treatment also but after a couple of months the depression returned and was quite disabling. I ended up taking Effexor again and the depression subsided. I have been taking Effexor in doses of 150 mg to 225 mg for the past 5 years and have been able to return to work
column7: enjoy my family and life in general. If I stop taking the Effexor I find myself slipping back into depression after just a few days. I am taking the time to write this to provide a note of encouragement to people who have not found a way out of their depression. As I said

column1: 485$Condition: Depression$3/4/2008 8:36:57 PM$Reviewer: persephone
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"Basically
column3: this drug has helped change my life. I've had problems with recurring major depressive disorder for as long as I can remember
column4: but it took one really bad episode in my adulthood to make me consider taking an antidepressant.

column1: I have to say
column2: taking the meds in combination with talk therapy has improved the quality of my life beyond measure.

column1: Most of the complaints people have here are about weight gain
column2: decreased libido and withdrawal effects.

column1: My weight gain started before taking Effexor
column2: so I can't blame it on that - I know it was due to a lifestyle change. I had decreased libido for about 6 months
column3: but then it returned back to normal.

column1: And FYI - you're going to have withdrawal effects when you stop taking any antidepressant. The key is to taper off slooooooowly and with the supervision of your doctor.
Not everyone needs to take Effexor (or any antidepressant) forever
column2: but for me - as long as it keeps me in remission
column3: I'm a happy camper."

column1: 521$Condition: Other$11/17/2007 11:12:00 PM$Reviewer: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$4$5$Effexor XR changed my life. I have panic disorder with agoraphobia but am now symptom free. I used to be housebound
column2: afraid even to be alone at home. Since I became symptomatic in 1969 I had taken tricyclics with some success but was never able to go anywhere very much. I was a virtual prisoner. Even the infomercial lady talked to me on the phone and realized I had a physical source to my problem. My brain is sensitive to epinephrine. I needed something that would control the norepinephrine in my brain. Guess what? That's what Effexor XR has done!! I started taking it in 1996 at age 45. I can drive anywhere
column3: go anywhere and do just about everything a normal person can do. I even went to Ireland and stayed alone in a small town for three weeks -- If someone would have told me that was possible before Effexor I would have said ""No Way!""

column1: It's not perfect. My worst side effect is insomnia. Better that than being a prisoner in my own home. The very worst things are FIRST The price. When might we see a generic equivalant? SECOND It is very hard to reduce the dosage or stop taking the medicine entirely. I experienced sort of a buzzing in my head (an actual noise)
column2: disorientation
column3: tremors
column4: sleeplessness
column5: somnabulation (sleepwalking) when I did sleep
column6: extreme hypertension that alarmed my internist so that I know I must be carefully watched if I ever have reason or desire to quit.

column1: If this medication doesn't work for your particular problem
column2: don't be afraid to try something else. I have a lady next door to me who has my problem and hasn't left her house in 40 years. All because she is afraid of side effects. The life she has missed
column3: it's sad.
